To date: methodological playground

section: Step I.II: How do I operationalize key variables?
text:
Step I.II: How do I operationalize key variables?
Key issues üö® (Hase et al., 2024)

Missing documentation by platforms (e.g., file structure)
Sudden changes in DDPs
Differences across languages & devices
Insufficient in-tool classification (e.g., LLM integration)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Let‚Äôs have a look at the technical set-up üíª:
https://github.com/eyra/mono
https://github.com/eyra/feldspar

title: Follow the User?!
section: Strategy to make the extraction work
text:
Strategy to make the extraction work

Take a look at the DDP; download it, best for multiple time periods and for different languages
Understand the structure of the JSON or CSV.
Get an example file running.
Write the code for the extraction script.
Test your script, first locally and then in the wild.
Adapt your script.

title: Follow the User?!
section: Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?
text:
Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?

Often: survey, then forwarding to an external site
Less often: Integration in existing survey infrastructure (Haim et al., 2023)

title: Follow the User?!
section: Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?
text:
Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?

Low response rates (e.g., Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024)

Behavioral intentions as ‚Äúwillingness to donate‚Äù high (79-52% of survey respondents)
Actual behavior as ‚Äúparticipation in data donation‚Äù low (37-12% of survey respondents)
Well known intention-behavior gap (Kmetty & Stefkovics, 2025)

Non-response bias
Primary used in non-probability panels (e.g.¬†online access panels)
Survey design strategies: For now, ü§ë is the only thing that works.
üëâ Again, we will talk about this in session 4Ô∏è‚É£.

title: Follow the User?!
text:
üì¢ Task 3: Classify search terms
Download the data for Task 4 from the workshop website. This contains YouTube searches collected from a German social media sample. Either discuss this (no-code group) or do this in R/Python (code group)‚Ä¶..

How you would clean the data?
How you would identify health-related searches using NLP methods?

title: Follow the User?!
section: Step II.II: How do I check for bias?
text:
Step II.II: How do I check for bias?

Errors in representation and measurements, e.g.

based on systematic drop-out (Pak et al., 2022)
based on systematic misclassification of digital traces (TeBlunthuis et al., 2024)


üëâ You know the drill: We will talk about this in session 4Ô∏è‚É£.

title: Follow the User?!
section: Step III.I: How do I analyze results?
text:
Step III.I: How do I analyze results?
Think carefully about‚Ä¶

How to create indices from different metrics (e.g., liking, sharing, or commenting on content)
Hierarchical structure (nested in time, metrics, platforms)
Skewed data, non-linearity

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Who are you?
Please raise your hand ü§ö if you ‚Ä¶.

are familiar with the term digital trace data
have worked with APIs
have worked with data donation
have worked with automated content analysis
regularly use programming languages (e.g., R, Python)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
About us: Frieder Rodewald

PhD, University of Mannheim (DFG project on data donation)
Research interests:

CSS (automated content analysis, digital traces, bias)
Privacy concerns & behavior
‚ÄúI study what people do online‚Äù

More info: github.com/frodew & frieder-rodewald.de

title: Follow the User?!
text:
About us: Valerie Hase

Akademische R√§tin a. Z./Postdoc, LMU Munich (prev.: University of Zurich & LSE)
Research interests:

CSS (automated content analysis, digital traces, bias, data access)
Digital journalism, crisis communication

More info: github.com/valeriehase & valerie-hase.com

title: Follow the User?!
section: What is the goal of this workshop?
text:
What is the goal of this workshop?

‚úÖ Understanding digital data traces as a type of data
‚úÖ Understanding data donation as a method of data access
‚úÖ Working through key steps of data donation methods (user & researcher view)
‚úÖ Discussing when (not) to use data donation studies
‚ùå Detailed implementation (e.g., server set-up, coding data extraction scripts)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
2. What is digital trace data? (Frieder)

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
text: Which examples for digital trace data you know? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
What is digital trace data?
Definition üí°: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena

e.g., tweets, likes, shares on social media
e.g., geo data (locations, movements)
e.g., digital payments
e.g., Spotify playlists

title: Follow the User?!
text:
What is digital trace data?
Definition üí°: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena

e.g., tweets, likes, shares on social media

Example: Instagram Like

title: Follow the User?!
text:
What is digital trace data?
Definition üí°: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena

e.g., tweets, likes, shares on social media

Example: Instagram Like

title: Follow the User?!
section: Where can we find/collect digital trace data?
text:
Where can we find/collect digital trace data?

Apps (e.g., running apps)
Social media platforms (e.g., Instagram)
Payment systems (e.g., Paypal)
Wearable devices (e.g., smart watch)

title: Follow the User?!
section: Which types of data does this include?
text:
Which types of data does this include?
Depending on the data collection method‚Ä¶ (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024):

often fine-grained (e.g., time-stamped)
often longitudinal (e.g., over years, within-individual change)
often less reactive (e.g., less concerns about social desirability)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Which (latent) constructs can we measure?

Internet use (Parry et al., 2021) related to ‚Ä¶

well-being (Ohme et al., 2024)
voting (Bach et al., 2021)

News engagement (Reiss, 2023) related to ‚Ä¶

news diversity (J√ºrgens & Stark, 2022)
public opinion formation (Yan et al., 2022)

Movements related to ‚Ä¶

Mobility during pandemics (Li et al., 2021)
Social networks (Sepulvado et al., 2022)

title: Follow the User?!
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)

‚ÄúHow many minutes a day do you use the internet to consume news?‚Äù

Source: Image by Scott Graham via Unsplash
‚Äûinternet‚Äù?
‚Äûnews‚Äù?
‚Äûhow many minutes‚Äù?

title: Follow the User?!
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)

Self-reported data subject to specific bias (Parry et al., 2021; Scharkow, 2016)
Response rates in surveys are declining (Luiten et al., 2020)

title: Follow the User?!
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)
Availabillity

cheap (e.g., via APIs)
large data sets (‚Äúbig data‚Äù)


Be careful: These ‚Äúadvantages‚Äù are often claimed, but not empirically proven.
Digital traces are neither necessarily less biased, nor cheaper, or larger (we will discuss this in Session 4Ô∏è‚É£).

title: Follow the User?!
text:
(Dis-)advantages of digital trace data

‚úÖ More fine-grained, often longitudinal measures due to timestamps
‚úÖ Partly measurement of new variables (e.g., algorithmic inference)
‚ùå Bias due to errors in representation and measurement
‚ùå Implementation can be expensive and cumbersome
‚ùå More data does not mean better data!

title: Follow the User?!
section: Summary: What is digital trace data? üìö
text:
Summary: What is digital trace data? üìö

Definition: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena
Further literature

Keusch & Kreuter (2021)
Haim & Hase (2023)
Ohme et al. (2024)

title: Follow the User?!
section: 3. How can we collect digital traces? (Valerie)
text:
3. How can we collect digital traces? (Valerie)

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
text: Which methods do you know/have you used for collecting digital trace data? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods

Platform-centric (based on platform cooperation)

API (J√ºnger, 2021)
Cooperation with platforms (Wagner, 2023)

User-centric (based on user cooperation and informed consent) or ‚Äúfollow the user‚Äù approaches (Caliandro, 2024)

Data donation (Carri√®re et al., 2024)
Linkage (Sloan et al., 2020)
Sensors (Struminskaya et al., 2021)
Tracking (Christner et al., 2022)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods

Restrictions of platform-centric methods

Discontinuation of APIs (Freelon, 2018)
Concerns about bias (Schatto-Eckrodt, 2022; Ulloa et al., 2025)

User-centric methods become more popular, given ‚Ä¶

Changes in law that enable such studies (GDPR, DSA)
Presumably (!) less biased data
Ethical considerations (informed consent)

title: Follow the User?!
section: Summary: How can we collect digital traces? üìö
text:
Summary: How can we collect digital traces? üìö

Summary

Central methods including platform-centric methods (e.g., APIs) and user-centric methods (e.g., data donation)
Key differences: control over samples & measurements, legal & ethical contexts

Further literature

Haim & Hase (2023)
Ohme et al. (2024)

text: Questions? ü§î

Session 2Ô∏è‚É£: Data Donation Studies (Participant Perspective)
üëâ Part of the SPP DFG Project Integrating Data Donations in Survey Infrastructure

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Agenda

What are data donation studies?
Participant perspective, including
2.1 üì¢ Task 1: Inspect your DDPs
2.2 üì¢ Task 2: Try donating your data


Image by Hope House Press via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
text:
1) What are data donation studies? (Valerie)

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Changes in legal contexts

EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

‚ÄúThe data subject shall have [‚Ä¶] access to the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 1)
‚ÄúThe controller shall provide a copy of the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 3)

According to ¬ß Art. 20, users must receive their data ‚Äúin a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format‚Äù (¬ß Art. 20, 1)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Changes in legal contexts

EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

‚ÄúThe data subject shall have [‚Ä¶] access to the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 1)
‚ÄúThe controller shall provide a copy of the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 3)

According to ¬ß Art. 20, users must receive their data ‚Äúin a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format‚Äù (¬ß Art. 20, 1)

üëâ Solution: Platforms offer data download packages (DDPs), which users can request and download to inspect data.
üëâ Consequence: Researchers uses DDPs as part of user-centric data donation studies.

title: Follow the User?!
text: Please raise your hand ‚úã : Who has ever tried to request their data from an online platform? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
What are data donation studies?
Definition üí°: Data donation studies are a user-centric method for collecting digital traces:

Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.
They can make their data packages (DDPs) available to science via data donation tools (DDTs), often in the context of surveys.
Researchers use CSS methods to filter, anonymize, and aggregate this data locally on participants‚Äô devices.
Participants can inspect/delete their data before any data is transferred.

title: Follow the User?!
section: Which types of data do DDPs contain?
text:
Which types of data do DDPs contain?
For platforms like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, for example‚Ä¶ (Hase et al., 2024)

User profiles (e.g., privacy settings)
Activities (e.g., friends, likes, searches, exposure, analog movements)
Content and context (e.g., ads watched, algorithmically inferred interests)

title: Follow the User?!
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to APIs (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)‚Ä¶

Control & informed consent of users
Longitudinal data without ‚Äúrate limits‚Äù
Partly additional measurements (e.g., exposure data; non-public data)

title: Follow the User?!
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to tracking (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)‚Ä¶

Retrospective & often more longitudinal
Partly additional measurements (e.g., algorithmic inferences)
Anchored in current provisions in law (for issues with tracking, see Edelson & McCoy, 2021)

üëâ but similarly burdensome for participants!

title: Follow the User?!
section: Summary: What are data donation studies? üìö
text:
Summary: What are data donation studies? üìö

Summary: User-centric method for collecting digital traces: Users download their data packages (DDPs) from platforms and make them available to science via data donation tools (DDTs).
Further literature:

Boeschoten et al. (2022)
Carri√®re et al. (2024)

Upload and inspect your data. Did you encounter any difficulties in sharing your data?

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Bias in Data Donation Studies
Similar to tracking studies, data donation characterized by (Hase et al., 2024; Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024):

Errors in representation (e.g., coverage error, non-response error)
Measurement errors (e.g., missing data, specification error)

üëâ Not necessarily less biased than survey data - but subject to different bias?
üëâ We will talk about this in Session 4Ô∏è‚É£.

title: My Presentation
text:
Basic Features

This is a basic slide, starting with a ## title.
You can wrap citations [@some_author] in another pair of brackets and add cite-class [[@some_author]]{.cite} to make the citations smaller.
If you want single slides with little content, you can do that in a code-block and a v-center-class to center the content.



template.qmd

::: {.v-center}

Some centered content here.

:::

title: My Presentation
text:
More Information

If you have further questions feel free to to check out the quarto documentation, specifically revealjs.
The quarto-cli community has also already answered the questions you might have in an issue or discussion! For example, check out how to add fontawesome icons to your quarto slides.
And if that does not help, you could submit an issue here and maybe I can help you out.

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Session 4Ô∏è‚É£: Bias & Outro
üëâ Part of the SPP DFG Project Integrating Data Donations in Survey Infrastructure

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Agenda

Bias in Data Donation Studies
What‚Äôs Next for Data Donation?
Outro


Image by Hope House Press via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
text:
1) Bias in Data Donation Studies (Valerie)

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
text:
What is bias?
Definition üí°: Deviations from the true value of a theoretical concept introduced by its measurement (Peytchev, 2013)

Non-systematic errors: random deviations influence variance of estimates
Systematic errors (or: bias): depend on omitted variables

üëâ Bias can influence descriptive results but also attenuate/inflate inferential conclusions.

title: Follow the User?!
text:
What is bias?

Errors in representation: Who participates in data donation studies?
Errors in measurement: Which latent concepts can we measure with data donation studies?


Source: Image from Boeschoten et al., 2022, p.¬†396

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation
For example ‚Ä¶

Coverage error: Who is (not) represented in the sampling frame? (e.g., social media users vs.¬†YouTube users)
Sampling error: Who is (not) represented in the sample? (e.g., non-probability samples)
Non-response error: Who does (not) want to participate in the data donation?
Compliance error: Who is (not) able to participate in the data donation?

title: Follow the User?!
text: What do you think: Which participant characteristics may correlate with non-response or non-compliance? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation
Example study by Hase & Haim (2024):

Source: Figure from Hase & Haim (2024)

title: Follow the User?!
text: Any ideas (from your discipline): How can we quantify/address errors in representation? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation: Quantification

Response rates across study stages
Para data as quality indicators (e.g., speeding)
Non-response bias (e.g.¬†traits of survey vs.¬†donation participants)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions

A posteriori strategies:

Infrastructure: Integration in probability-based panels
Survey design strategies (e.g., incentives, study framing)
DDT design (e.g.¬†UX-perspective)

Post hoc strategies:

Statistical modeling (e.g., weighting, see Pak et al., 2022)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions
For now: limited studies, limited success of existing solutions

Source: Figure from Hase & Haim (2024)

title: Follow the User?!
text: What do you think: How could errors in measurements sneak into data donation studies? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in measurement
For example ‚Ä¶

Construct (in-)validity: How do DDP variables relate to latent measurements? (e.g., likes vs.¬†political participation)
Measurement error: How correct is data in our DDP? (e.g., missing data)
Extraction error: Did we extract all relevant files and variables?

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in measurements
Example study by Valkenburg et al. (2024):

Source: Figure from Valkenburg et al.¬†(2024)

title: Follow the User?!
text: Any ideas (from your discipline): How can we quantify/address errors in measurements? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in measurement: Quantification

Para data (e.g., failed uploads)
Correlation between self-reported and observed behavior
Multi Trait Multi Method (MTMM) approaches (Cernat et al., 2024)
Estimation of misclassification effects (TeBlunthuis et al., 2024)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions

A posteriori strategies:

Talk to everyone (e.g., IRB, Data Strward)
Repeated testing & DDP download
Simulate downstream errors (Bosch et al., 2024)

Post hoc strategies:

Multiverse approaches
Statistical error correction (TeBlunthuis et al., 2024)
Error documentation (Gebru et al., 2021)

title: Follow the User?!
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions
Example study by Hase et al. (2024):

Source: Figure from Hase et al.¬†2024

title: Follow the User?!
text: Questions? ü§î

title: Follow the User?!
section: 2) What‚Äôs next for data donation studies? (Frieder)
text:
2) What‚Äôs next for data donation studies? (Frieder)

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Follow the User?!
section: The road ahead I: Advancing the method
text:
The road ahead I: Advancing the method

Multimodal & cross-platform data üì∏ (Wedel et al., 2024)
In-tool, local classification (e.g., local SML/LLMs?)
Workflow/UX-perspective


Source: Image by DariuszSankowski via Pixabay

title: Follow the User?!
section: The road ahead II: Data as a political tool
text:
The road ahead II: Data as a political tool

Platforms do (willingly?) not provide data according to the GDPR/DSA (Hase et al., 2024)
The EU has started to sanction platforms like X/TikTok
DSA may become the subject of larger geo-political debates with the USA (Seiling et al., 2025)


Source: Image by WilliamCho via Pixabay

title: Follow the User?!
section: The road ahead III: Can we improve & apply the method?
text:
The road ahead III: Can we improve & apply the method?

Can the method actually be applied for empirical research? (few examples, like Thorson et al., 2021; Wojcieszak et al., 2024)
Requires interdisciplinary perspectives (e.g., addressing bias, integration in probability-based panels)


Source: Image by Vladislav Babienko via Pixabay

title: Follow the User?!
text: Questions? ü§î
